awd_titl_txt: UNS: A functional nanocomposite-based biosensor for real-time ambulatory monitoring of salivary biomarkers
awd_abstract_narration:
1512816 Cheng, Li-Jing 


This research will develop a novel sensor device which will be able to measure molecules that are found in saliva when a person is under psychological stress.  The study if successful will enable measurement of stress markers in ambulatory setting.  Because the biosensor will be equipped with wireless connectivity, one can monitor stress experienced by the individual remotely. 


Real-time, detection of the stress salivary biomarkers enables assessment of stress levels in individuals. The salivary biomarkers are typically analyzed by fluorescence immunoassay and enzyme kinetic method which cannot be done in situ. The proposed stress biosensor built in a wearable configuration, will significantly benefit those regularly involved in stress-intensive activities, such as soldiers, pilots, and emergency care professionals. With the sensing function, stress and fatigue could be detected early in order to avoid impairment it may cause. Intellectual Merit: The proposed sensor consists of a composite of biopolymer impregnated with antibodies against saliva biomarkers, and nanoparticle electronics that measures changes in tunneling current upon analyte binding. This approach enables sensitive, specific and reversible detection of neutrally charged cortisol and D-amylase without addition of chemical reporters or redox reagents for signal transduction. Such capability overcomes the limits encountered in charge-based transistor/nanowire biosensors or electrochemical biosensing techniques. A passive RFID system will be integrated into the sensor for wireless monitoring of salivary biomarkers. The study will provide insights into the science of functional materials, nanoscale electron transport, mass transport in confined geometries and device integration. Broader impacts: The goal of the proposed education and outreach effort is to foster the development of a diverse science and engineering workforce with a deep understanding of functional materials, nanotechnology, and devices for biosensing and signal transduction. To achieve this goal, the education and outreach objectives are:  to develop new lab class for teaching biosensor and medical devices that allow students to conduct experiments involving, surface chemistry, molecular detection and mass transport in microfluidics, and to recruit and retain women and minorities in science and engineering careers by engaging minority undergraduate and high school students in summer research projects and through participation in our SESEY summer camp, which offers research experience in engineering fields for high school girls and minority students, and ASE program, which provides an eight-week summer apprenticeship to high school students in our research labs. A hierarchical mentorship structure is proposed in which students at each level will have the opportunity to serve as mentors for younger students.

por.por_cntn:
Most medical diagnostics rely on multiple types of laboratory-based testing methods, which are time-consuming and require trained personnel. The diagnosis of stress-related diseases associated with disorders of steroid hormones, however, cannot rely on a single analysis of these hormones or a one-day average or be referenced to a population-wide average baseline. Instead, it requires to map the hormone levels of an individual patient throughout multiple 24-hour cycles. Existing clinical steroid hormone measurements utilize swab saliva collection at multiple time points, send to a lab to await results, and track concentrations over time to look for trends that could be indicative of the onset of disease. These methods require high-cost, laborious tests, providing no way for the continuous monitoring needed for real-time stress management and point-of-care diagnosis. This three-year project was to develop a new type of sensor that allows real-time monitoring of salivary biomarker cortisol.

In the three years of the project, we explored new bioresponsive materials and device structures to enable sensitive and stable detection of cortisol. The development led to a new hybrid polymer-based sensor that transduces the binding of target cortisol to the change in electrochemical response without additional chemical reagents in the analyte solution. The reagent-free detection simplified the detection workflow and allowed to realize the sensor in a wearable fashion. The sensor exhibited a detection limit of 100 pM and a dynamic range of more than 1 µM, the range suitable for clinic diagnosis. Apart from the sensor and material development, we also prototyped a cm-scale wireless sensor module for remote control and acquisition sensing data through an Android application. The biosensor technology for continuous real-time monitoring is expected to open up new applications in non-invasive clinical diagnosis. However, there remain several technical challenges in developing sensing materials with long-term stability. The research in this project established an in-depth understanding of the design of the sensor materials and device structures, which will lead to further improvement of the sensor performance. The sensor and wireless sensor module developed in this project provide the baseline for the implementation of an integrated in-mouth sensor system.

Overall, the project provided multiple educational opportunities. Three graduate students leveraged this project for their master and Ph.D. studies on biosensors and nanoaterials under the supervision of the project PI. Six undergraduate students from the School of EECS participated in the design project associated with this award through a three-term Senior Project Class in year 2017 and year 2018 to develop two types of wireless biosensing modules and explore the research fields of biosensor technologies. Work under this grant contributed to three invention disclosures, two published journal articles with another two journal manuscripts under preparation, and more than ten conference papers that contain specific results from the project. The products of the research project also support the lecture materials and several lab demos in the two senior and graduate-level courses related to biosensors and nanomaterials. More than fifty students from different engineering backgrounds joined the classes to learn the fundamentals of biosensor technologies and biomaterials. The students also participated in multiple lab demonstration activities, including electrochemical impedance measurement, fluorescence detection, and surface chemistry. The connection between research project and teaching through the lab demos was found to provide the students an inspiring learning environment to explore biosensor and medical technologies.
